title: How to Make Turkey Stock

steps.headline: Chop the onions, celery, and carrots into large pieces.
steps.description: Leave the peel on 2 onions and cut each into quarters. Then cut 4 stalks of celery and 4 carrots into 3 in (7.6 cm) pieces. Put the vegetables into a stockpot that's at least 5 US quarts (4.7 L) in size. The onion peels will give the stock a nice golden color.

steps.headline: Add the turkey carcass, peppercorns, and herbs.
steps.description: Place the carcass of 1 cooked turkey [about 4 pounds (1.8 kg)] into the stockpot and add 1 teaspoon (3 g) of whole black peppercorns. If you'd like to add herbs, put a few sprigs of fresh parsley or thyme into the pot.Tip: Try to remove most of the skin from the carcass before you put it in the pot. This will make a clearer stock that doesn't contain as much fat.

steps.headline: Pour in enough water to cover the carcass by 1 inch (2.5 cm).
steps.description: Use cold water from the tap and ensure that the vegetables and turkey carcass are completely submerged. If you use hot water, the turkey stock will be cloudy.

steps.headline: Bring the water to a boil over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Put the lid on the stockpot and turn the burner on. Leave the water until it comes to a full rolling boil. You should see steam escaping from the side of the lid. Clear lids are great since you can easily look into the pot to see if the water is boiling. If you don't have a clear lid, just look for the steam escaping from under the lid.

steps.headline: Simmer the stock for 3 to 3 1/2 hours.
steps.description: Turn the burner down to medium, so the liquid bubbles gently, and take the lid off of the pot. Simmer the stock and stir it occasionally until the vegetables soften. About 1/2 of the liquid in the pot should evaporate once the stock has finished cooking. You may need to adjust the burner if the stock begins to boil or it stops simmering.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and taste the stock.
steps.description: Stir the turkey stock and dip a small spoon into it. Taste the stock and add salt according to your taste. The stock should have a rich turkey flavor. If the turkey stock still tastes watery, simmer it for another 30 minutes and then taste it again.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 450 °F (232 °C) and put the turkey on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Get out a rimmed baking sheet and place 3 ⁄2 pounds (1,600 g) of raw turkey wings on it. If you have it, you can also put the raw turkey's neck on the sheet. The rimmed baking sheet will catch the juices as the turkey parts roast.

steps.headline: Roast the turkey wings for 45 minutes.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet into the preheated oven and roast the turkey wings until they turn golden brown. To help them cook evenly, use tongs to turn the wings over halfway through the roasting time. Roasting the turkey parts will give the turkey stock a richer flavor.

steps.headline: Put the roasted turkey into a stockpot.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and remove the baking sheet from the oven. Use tongs or a slotted spoon to transfer the turkey wings to a stockpot that's at least 5 US quarts (4.7 L) in size. Then tilt the pan and drain off the fatty liquid that's pooling on the baking sheet. Using a large stockpot will ensure that the stock doesn't boil over as it cooks.

steps.headline: Pour water onto the baking sheet and scrape up the roasted bits.
steps.description: Slowly pour 2 cups (470 ml) of water onto the baking sheet that you used to roast the turkey wings. Use a wooden spoon to scrape the sheet to loosen anything that's stuck to the bottom of the sheet. Then pour the liquid into the stockpot with the turkey. These roasted bits will add a rich depth of flavor to the turkey stock.

steps.headline: Add the chopped vegetables and seasonings to the stockpot.
steps.description: Put the chopped onion, carrot, and celery stalk into the stockpot and add 4 sprigs of fresh parsley along with 4 sprigs of fresh thyme. Put 12 whole peppercorns and 1 bay leaf in as well.Tip: Using whole peppercorns will give flavor to your stock without making it cloudy.

steps.headline: Pour in 10 cups (2.4 L) of water and turn the burner on to medium.
steps.description: Once the water begins to bubble, adjust the burner so the liquid simmers gently. You should also leave the lid off of the pot. This will allow some of the water to evaporate and the flavor to concentrate. Use cold water instead of hot or boiling water. Starting with cold water will keep the stock clear.

steps.headline: Simmer the stock for about 4 hours.
steps.description: Stir the stock occasionally and monitor the liquid level in the stockpot. Taste the stock once the liquid is reduced by at least 1/3. Now is a good time to add salt according to your taste. If the stock still tastes watery, let it simmer for another 30 minutes before tasting it again.

steps.headline: Scoop out and discard large bones from the turkey stock.
steps.description: Before you strain the turkey stock, use a slotted spoon to scoop up the largest turkey bones. Throw these in the trash along with any of the large vegetable pieces you scoop up with them. Removing the large pieces from the stock will make it easier to strain into a bowl.

steps.headline: Strain the stock into a large bowl.
steps.description: Place a large bowl into the sink and set a fine-mesh strainer over it. Use both hands to carefully pick up the stockpot and slowly pour the stock into the bowl.Tip: If the stockpot is too heavy to easily lift, ladle the stock into the strainer or pour it into a smaller pot. Then pour the liquid from the small pot through the strainer. Discard the solids that are left in the fine-mesh strainer.

steps.headline: Cool the stock for 30 minutes and put it into containers.
steps.description: Leave the stock to cool a little at room temperature and then pour it into the storage containers of your choice. For example, pour the stock into food-safe sealable bags, jars, or cartons. Since this makes so much stock, consider storing the stock in a variety of container sizes. This will make it easy to use the stock in different recipes.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the stock for up to 1 week.
steps.description: Label the containers with the date you made the stock and refrigerate them. For longer term storage, freeze the turkey stock for up to 3 months. To thaw it, place a container of stock in the refrigerator overnight. You'll notice a layer of white fat float to the top of the stock after you refrigerate or freeze it. Simply use a spoon to scrape off and discard the fat.
